guideline: Consume oily fish and nuts to maintain cell membrane integrity and promote neuronal growth. Biological Impact: Associated with improved cognitive function, preserved white matter integrity, and reduced risk of cognitive decline. Specific Outcome: High intake correlates with lower presence and slower progression of white matter hyperintensities.
source: IJHSR28.pdf; HSR2-8-e71240.pdf

guideline: Avoid diets with a high Glycemic Index (GI) to prevent rapid glucose fluctuations. Biological Impact: High glycemic load triggers counter-regulatory hormones (cortisol, adrenaline) which can cause changes in anxiety and irritability. Specific Outcome: Longitudinal data shows an association between progressively higher dietary glycemic index and the incidence of depressive symptoms.
source: BMJ - Poor nutrition may be a causal factor...

guideline: Adhere to a diet high in vegetables, fruits, nuts, and olive oil to protect gray matter volume. Biological Impact: Associated with increased volumes of the thalamus, putamen, pallidum, hippocampus, and nucleus accumbens. Specific Outcome: Adherence reduces markers of inflammation, which are linked to hippocampal dysfunction and blood-brain barrier damage.
source: HSR2-8-e71240.pdf; BMJ - Poor nutrition may be a causal factor...

guideline: Consume high-fiber and fermented foods to support the Gut-Brain Axis. Biological Impact: Promotes growth of beneficial bacteria that produce neurotransmitters like serotonin and dopamine; reduces production of inflammatory metabolites. Specific Outcome: Probiotics can alter the brain's response to emotional tasks and reduce depressive symptoms.
source: IJHSR28.pdf; BMJ - Poor nutrition may be a causal factor...

guideline: Limit intake of processed foods, refined sugars, and unhealthy fats. Biological Impact: Linked to reductions in brain structures, specifically reduced left hippocampal volume. Specific Outcome: High consumption of processed foods at age 10 is linked to smaller cerebral white matter volume.
source: HSR2-8-e71240.pdf

guideline: Adherence to a traditional diet (fish, plant-based) protects against brain atrophy. Biological Impact: Negatively associated with Gray Matter (GM) atrophy in women, but not significantly in men. Specific Outcome: Preservation of total GM volume specifically in the parietal lobe.
source: HSR2-8-e71240.pdf

guideline: Avoid soft-textured ultra-processed foods which increase eating rate. Biological Impact: Soft textures decrease oral processing time, outpacing the satiety response signal (Pillar 3 of appetite control). Specific Outcome: Higher eating rates (g/min) drive increased calorie intake; energy intake is significantly higher on ultra-processed diets compared to unprocessed diets.
source: Wiley - Neurobiology of eating behavior...

guideline: Consume foods rich in polyphenols (fruits, vegetables, tea) for neuroprotection. Biological Impact: Modulates neuroinflammation and promotes synaptic plasticity. Specific Outcome: Green tea consumption is related to smaller hippocampal volume changes (neuroprotective effect).
source: IJHSR28.pdf; HSR2-8-e71240.pdf

guideline: Monitor sugar and fat intake during adolescence to prevent reward threshold alterations. Biological Impact: Adolescents have hyper-responsive reward centers (ventral striatum); high-fat/sugar foods can alter dopamine connectivity and executive control. Specific Outcome: Obesity and diet can blunt prefrontal cortex functioning, negatively influencing future decision making.
source: Wiley - Neurobiology of eating behavior...

guideline: Limit high-calorie meals rich in saturated fats to prevent immune activation. Biological Impact: Stimulates immune activation and systemic inflammation, which is associated with depression. Specific Outcome: People with depression score significantly higher on measures of 'dietary inflammation'.
source: BMJ - Poor nutrition may be a causal factor...

guideline: Avoid hypercaloric and high-fat diets during pregnancy. Biological Impact: Maternal high-fat diet alters the density of hypothalamic projections and programs mesocorticolimbic reward circuits in offspring. Specific Outcome: Maternal stress and diet can lead to tactile hyperresponsivity and problem behaviors in children.
source: Wiley - Neurobiology of eating behavior...

guideline: Consume foods that stimulate GLP-1 and PYY release (gut-brain axis peptides). Biological Impact: Nutrients in the gut stimulate the release of GLP-1 and PYY from L-cells, which induce satiety and inhibit gastric emptying. Specific Outcome: Prebiotics like inulin-type fructans promote the release of anorexigenic peptides GLP-1 and PYY.
source: Wiley - Neurobiology of eating behavior...

guideline: Maintain optimal Vitamin D levels to support neurotransmitter synthesis and preventing brain atrophy. Biological Impact: Regulates genetic expression of serotonin and dopamine; controls Nerve Growth Factor (NGF) and Glial Cell Line-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (GDNF). Specific Outcome: Deficiency is linked to thinner cortex, enlarged lateral ventricles (atrophy), and white matter damage connecting cognitive/emotional regions.
source: DrOracle - Mechanism of Vitamin D in Depression; ResearchGate - Vitamin D and Mental Health

guideline: Ensure adequate magnesium intake to modulate the HPA axis and prevent hyper-excitability. Biological Impact: Acts as a voltage-gated antagonist at the NMDA receptor (blocking excitatory glutamate) and an agonist at GABA receptors (calming effect). Specific Outcome: Deficiency increases catecholamine release (adrenaline) and lowers the threshold for stress; supplementation can alleviate anxiety and irritability.
source: NCBI - Magnesium and Stress; CanPrev - Magnesium, Anxiety, Depression

guideline: Consume zinc-rich foods to regulate synaptic activity and prevent glutamate excitotoxicity. Biological Impact: Modulates glutamatergic neurons and stabilizes protein structures essential for neurotransmission; high concentration in the hippocampus and amygdala. Specific Outcome: Deficiency leads to HPA axis disruption (elevated corticosterone) and depression-like behaviors; supplementation reduces depressive symptom scores.
source: PMC - Role of Zinc in Neurological Diseases; MDPI - Zinc and CNS Disorders

guideline: Incorporate curcumin to enhance Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) and serotonin. Biological Impact: Inhibits Monoamine Oxidase (MAO) enzymes, increasing serotonin/dopamine; reduces neuroinflammation and oxidative stress. Specific Outcome: Chronic administration prevents depressive-like behavior by regulating synaptic structural plasticity in the amygdala.
source: Oxford Academic - Curcumin and Amygdala Plasticity; PMC - Curcumin in Depression

guideline: Adopt intermittent fasting protocols to stimulate neurotrophic factors and improve bioenergetics. Biological Impact: Increases BDNF and Neurotrophin 3 (NT3); promotes ketone body production (3-Î²-hydroxybutyrate) which fuels neurons when glucose is low. Specific Outcome: Enhances hippocampal neurogenesis, improves insulin sensitivity in neurons, and reduces inflammatory mediators like IL-6 and CRP.
source: PMC - Impact of Intermittent Fasting on BDNF; Journal of Drug Delivery & Therapeutics - Neuroprotective Effects of IF

guideline: Prevent even mild dehydration (loss of >2% body mass) to maintain executive function. Biological Impact: Dehydration increases cortisol (stress hormone) production and decreases serotonin/dopamine; alters electrolyte balance affecting neurotransmission. Specific Outcome: Mild dehydration impairs attention, executive function, and motor coordination; linked to increased anxiety, fatigue, and 'brain fog'.
source: Cleveland Clinic - Dehydration and Mental Health; Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation

guideline: Consume specific psychobiotics like Bifidobacterium longum or Lactobacillus helveticus. Biological Impact: Modulates the HPA axis to reduce cortisol; communicates with the brain via the vagus nerve and immune pathways. Specific Outcome: Depletion of Coprococcus and Dialister bacteria is consistently found in patients with depression; specific strains reduce urinary free cortisol.
source: PMC - Gut Microbiome and Mental Health; Taylor & Francis - Psychobiotics

guideline: Combine natural anti-inflammatory compounds for synergistic mood benefits. Biological Impact: Reduces production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and enhances neurotrophic factor expression. Specific Outcome: Synergistic effect observed in ameliorating anxiety and depression with minimal side effects compared to placebo.
source: PMC - Nutrition and Neuro Sciences Editorial

guideline: Monitor selenium levels to support memory function, particularly in at-risk genetic groups. Biological Impact: Critical for antioxidant defense in the brain; interaction with APOE4 status affects memory outcomes. Specific Outcome: Linked to episodic memory performance in APOE4-negative elderly participants.
source: PMC - Nutrition and Neuro Sciences Editorial

guideline: Limit consumption of processed, sweet, and fatty foods to maintain effective communication between reward and evaluation centers. Biological Impact: Chronic consumption is associated with reduced Resting-State Functional Connectivity (rsFC) between the Nucleus Accumbens (reward perception) and the Lateral Orbitofrontal Cortex (hedonic valuation). Specific Outcome: Reduced top-down cognitive control over food choices; higher emotional eating scores; altered conflict resolution processing in the Anterior Cingulate Cortex.
source: Frontiers in Nutrition - Coquery et al. (2022)

guideline: Reduce intake of processed meats and refined sugars to preserve motivation-control pathways. Biological Impact: Inverse correlation observed between the Right Insula (gustatory/interoception) and the Anterior Cingulate Cortex (conflict monitoring). Specific Outcome: Impaired ability to resolve cognitive conflicts during food choices (e.g., choosing between health vs. taste), leading to less efficient decision-making.
source: Frontiers in Nutrition - Coquery et al. (2022)
